subject: Re: [junit] JSP Validation (Was: HTML/XHTML Validation w/JUnit)
msgSnippet: Do you want to validate that the .jsp file is a valid JSP document, or do you want to validate that the output of the .jsp file (probably HTML etc.) is valid?
messageBody:
Do you want to validate that the .jsp file is a valid JSP document, or
do you want to validate that the output of the .jsp file (probably HTML
etc.) is valid? Both options are valid, but are definitely not the same
thing.

My original question that started this thread was more aimed at the
second option (validating the output of the JSP, not the contents of the
.jsp file itself).

I am not aware of any validators for the "common" JSP format that most
people use. When I say "common" I mean a JSP in which you have scriplet,
expressions and declaration tags mixed with taglibs, jsp tags and
template tags. The obvious reason for this is that these documents don't
really follow a nice referenceable document model (i.e. they are not
readily XML parseable). If you can write a JSP using the JSP XML syntax
(detailed in the JSP spec) then you can validate with a regular
validating XML parser. The trick is that it becomes cumbersome to
include valid XML tags around all the embedded Java code throughout the
page - this is the reason we opted not to bother.

However, there seems to be some light on the horizon to solve this
problem. We have been experimenting with the EL features from JSTL and
have found we can eliminate most, if not all, of our scriptlets etc. In
this case the need for cumbersome additional XML tags disappears and
writing the JSP in the XML syntax becomes pretty easy. Then you could
use the previously mentioned validating XML parser to validate your JSPs.

Craig
